text: INT: GEORGEвЂ™S HOUSE - BEDROOM. MORNING 1962 -- CONTINUO GEORGE V.O. For the past eight months waking up has actually hurt. The cold realization that I am still here slowly sets in. George, with bed hair, still sweating, untangles himself from the sheets and sits up. He holds onto his head as if pain. A pile of clothes is in the chair next to the bed. Books magazines are loosely stacked next to the end table. Ther is an empty scotch bottle on the floor. The room is dark in disarray. The second hand is now ticking loudly.
I was never terribly fond of waking up. He rises, navigates the grid of letters, and walks to the bathroom.
Relieving himself at the toilet. Standing in the shower letting the hot water wash over hi GEORGE V.O. I was never one to jump out of bed and greet the day with a smile like Jim was. Shaving.
I used to want to punch him sometimes in the morning he was so happy. Taking a handful of aspirin

I always used to tell him that only fools greet the day with a smile, that only fools could possibly escape the simple truth that now isnвЂ™t simply now: itвЂ™s a cold reminder. One day later than yesterday, one year later than last year and that sooner or later it will come.
Scrubbing his fingernails briskly with a brush.
He used to laugh at me and then give me a kiss on the cheek INT. GEORGEвЂ™S HOUSE - BEDROOM. MORNING -- MINUTES LATER

Opening an extremely organized drawer and taking out a pa of perfectly folded black socks. GEORGE V.O. It takes time in the morning for me to become George, time to adjust to what is expected of George and how he is to behave. Opening another equally organized drawer and pulling out immaculately pressed and folded white shirt.

By the time I have dressed and put the final layer of polish on the now slightly stiff but quite perfect George I know fully what part IвЂ™m supposed to play. George runs a brush over his shoes. He dabs the back of his neck with cologne. END SERIES OF SHOTS. Standing at his dresser, George adjusts his tie and looks at himself intently in the mirror as our camera glides up George's body to his face to reveal the now fully realize public face of George.
Looking in the mirror staring back at me isnвЂ™t so much a face as the expression of a predicament.
(whispering aloud to himself) Just get through the goddamn day.  GEORGE V.O. A bit melodramatic I guess.

George walks down the hallway. As he approaches the livin room he glances out the window and sees JIM. GEORGE V.O. But then again my heart has been broken. JIM, 34, handsome and well built in a classical American is waxing a surfboard on a pair of saw horses. Two more surfboards lie on the bright green lawn behind him. A bla and white, smooth fox terrier, like the dead dog in the c lies in the sun on his side next to Jim. Another smaller, but identical dog is biting at the collar of the first do Jim is disciplining the smaller dog.

I feel as If I am sinking, drowning, canвЂ™t breathe. George stares back at Jim but his expression is suddenly changed by a sharp pain that grips his chest. He holds onto the louvered rail that separates the hall f the living room to avoid falling over. He stands still an takes a deep breath. When the pain passes, he looks back out of the window. No surfboards. No Jim. No dogs. Just a brown over-grown lawn George closes his eyes, and takes a deep breath. He makes his way down the hallway and into the kitchen.

George plugs in the toaster and opens the bread box. No bread. He opens the refrigerator. No bread. He opens the freezer to find a loaf of white bread frozen solid. He dr the bread on the counter with a thud. Irritated he bangs bread several times on the kitchen counter. He abandons t loaf of bread and begins making himself a pot of coffee.  7.

INT. GEORGEвЂ™S HOUSE - DINING AREA. MORNING -- MINUTES L George is seated at the table having his morning coffee a the phone rings. George looks at his watch. 7:40. He look back at the ringing phone and decides not to answer it. FLASHBACK - INT. GEORGEвЂ™S HOUSE - LIVING ROOM. DAY (194 George and Jim are standing in the completely new and absolutely empty house for the first time. It is stunning The starkness of it then is a total contrast to the house today. This is the house before it had a life.
ArenвЂ™t you going to say something?
Are you kidding? ItвЂ™s spectacular George is quietly staring at Jim with a faint smile on hi face. Jim smiles when he realizes this, then slips up clo to George and moves toward him for a kiss.
What are you doing? George pushes him away. Nervously looking out of the larg plate glass window.
Jim, stop it. I donвЂ™t think you're quite ready for life in a glass house.
Drapes, old man. Jim moves in for a kiss only to be held back by George.
You're the one whoвЂ™s always saying that weвЂ™re invisible.
ThatвЂ™s not exactly what I meant.  George gives in and the two men begin to kiss.

WE PULL BACK to reveal George alone in the house, across dining area and living room and out the pivoting glass do and across the dead lawn. GeorgeвЂ™s house is modest in s yet has dynamic lines. It is an example of very bold architecture, circa 1948, that has become somewhat ramsha over time. We take in the full view of George in his worl as the phone continues to ring.

George's empty bedroom as the phone continues to ring. Surfboards leaning against a wall in the garage. Books and architectural models on the living room shelves next to a drafting table. END SERIES OF SHOTS. We cut back to George staring into space for several beat as the phone continues to ring. GEORGE V.O. For the first time in my life I canвЂ™t see my future. Every day goes by in a haze, but today I have decided will be different. INT. GEORGEвЂ™S HOUSE - BEDROOM. MORNING -- MINUTES LATER

As George stands in front of his book case, the phone sta to ring again. George looks across the room at the phone which sits on a small table next to an upholstered club chair. GEORGE V.O. Finally. You know it has been raining here all day and IвЂ™ve been trapped in this house waiting for you to call.

Goodbye Mr. Falconer. George replaces the receiver. As he does, it misses the cradle and falls to the floor, the dial tone continues to hum. He sits looking blankly ahead in total disbelief. Bye, old man. We linger on Charley as she hangs up the phone. We see th joy in her face. She has a reason to live. INT. GEORGEвЂ™S HOUSE - LIVING ROOM. MORNING -- CONTINUOU George is coming down the hall. As he rushes toward the front door, he practically knocks over his cleaning woman ALVA, arriving with a bag of groceries and the newspaper under her arm. Alva is a kind, Hispanic woman in her mid 40's.

there so please donвЂ™t move them. And my pen leaked all over the bed. IвЂ™m sorry about the sheets.

Alva?

even read the article that I gave you on bomb shelters? Ours is almost done. We had 3 different contractors work on it so none of them know what weвЂ™ve got, then we're having the outside of it landscaped so no one will know itвЂ™s there.

Sir, on page 79, Mr. Propter says that the stupidest text in the Bible is: вЂњthey hated me without a cause." Does he mean the Nazis were right to hate the Jews? Is Huxley an anti-Semite?
No.  26. The class stares at George, expecting more from such a provocative question.

No, Mr. Huxley is not an anti Semite. The Nazis were obviously wrong to hate the Jews. But their hating the Jews was not without a cause... But the cause wasnвЂ™t real. The cause was imagined. The cause was FEAR. Curious stares.

LetвЂ™s leave the Jews out of this for a moment and think of another minority. One that can go unnoticed if it needs to. George looks directly at WALTER, a slightly effeminate yo man, who turns away embarrassed.

There are all sorts of minorities, blondes for example, but a minority is only thought of as one when it constitutes some kind of threat to the majority. A real threat or an imagined one. And therein lies the FEAR. And, if the minority is somehow invisible... Another glance at Walter.

always is a cause. And the cause is FEAR. Minorities are just people. People... Again a subtle look at Walter.

LetвЂ™s just talk about fear. Fear after all, is our real enemy. Fear is taking over our world. Fear is being used as a tool of manipulation in our society. Fear that weвЂ™re going to be attacked, fear that there are communists lurking around every corner, fear that some little Caribbean country that doesnвЂ™t believe in our way of life poses a threat to us. This is Charley at her best and not t same Charley we saw earlier. She has made quite an effort and she looks beautiful. She kisses George on the cheek as they embrace.

head_text.subj: A QUICK FLASHBACK OF GEORGE SOBBING IN THE RAIN IN CHARLE

text: Back to the present, George pulls away from Charley.  58.
You look divine. As chic as ever. George is genuinely happy to see Charley.
Come on in. INT. CHARLEYвЂ™S HOUSE - ENTRY HALL. NIGHT -- CONTINUOUS George follows Charley as they walk together through the house.
Oh God. It smells awfully of cooking in here doesnвЂ™t it?
It smells great. IвЂ™m starving WhereвЂ™s Louisa? INT. CHARLEYвЂ™S HOUSE - SUN ROOM. NIGHT -- CONTINUOUS
I gave her the night off. IвЂ™m cooking myself.
You are?
Yes, and IвЂ™m trying something new.
Charley darling, you cooking is new.

DonвЂ™t be smart. IвЂ™m in a good mood tonight and IвЂ™m going to be fun IвЂ™ve made two early New Years resolutions. One, no more talk about awful ex-husbands and children who donвЂ™t give a damn  59.
And the other one?
One what?
Resolution.
Oh, resolution number two! More smoking and more drinking and screw it all! So, come mix me up a drink I'll have a gin and tonic please and watch out baby!

Coming up. INT. CHARLEYвЂ™S HOUSE - LIVING ROOM. NIGHT -- CONTINUOUS The interior of the living room is almost all white. This is very definitely the house of a stylish woman. There is white shag carpet on the floor, a fire burning, a large curved sectional sofa in the center of the room and an elaborate dining table set for two in a window at the far end of the room. As they walk into the living room George turns to the wel stocked drinks table and mixes them both a drink. Charley sits down on the sofa in front of the fire.
It was sweet of you to come tonight.
Sweet had nothing to do with it. I needed to see you.
Oh come off it. Whenever you do something sweet, you're too ashamed to admit it.  60. George hands Charley her drink and sits down next to her.
To our early New Years Resolutions.
And just what are your resolutions by the way?
To let go of the past. Completely, entirely, and forever. They raise their glasses and smile at each other. Charley looks George up and down.
Light me up Geo, will you... Charley looks Geo in the eyes. George leans forward for t table lighter.
Darling, you donвЂ™t look well. Do you remember when you had your little heart attack last year?
It wasnвЂ™t a heart attack.
Well whatever it was darling you donвЂ™t look so hot.
IвЂ™m great. Never been better. Just tired. I haven't been sleeping

Geo, itвЂ™s normal. You were with Jim for 16 years. I think about Richard everyday too. ItвЂ™s hard being alone. At least you have a job and a life. (beat) LetвЂ™s have a bit of dinner shall we? Because IвЂ™ve worked so hard...  61. INT. CHARLEYвЂ™S HOUSE - LIVING ROOM. NIGHT -- LATER They've finished their dinner, and a bottle of champagne.
Really? Charley lights another cigarette. CHARLEY (CONTвЂ™D) What are you talking about?
Seriously, вЂњoldвЂќ doesnвЂ™t exist anymore. A student yesterday called me a вЂњsenior citizenвЂќ.

I wouldn't mind if вЂњoldвЂќ didnвЂ™t exist, but IвЂ™m not sure вЂњseniorвЂќ is what IвЂ™m shooting for either Charley catches a reflection of herself in the glass of the window and smooths her cheek up a bit with her well manicured hand.
ItвЂ™s all becoming so bland... itвЂ™s not why I came to America. ItвЂ™s like a complete breakdown of culture and manners.
Well, the young ones have no manners. The other day at the car wash I had a young man look me up and down and actually ask me if I was a natural blonde!
No. What did you say?
I looked him straight in the eye (MORE)
and said: вЂњWell, letвЂ™s just say that if I stood on my head I would be a natural brunette with lovely breath.вЂќ
You did not!
I did! And the amusing thing was that it went right over his head! They both laugh hysterically.

You had a mouth on you even back in London. Do you remember that old lesbian who threw her drink at you because you asked her if she was hung like a donut!? They practically fall out of their chairs laughing at thi one. Their laughing tapers off as Charley takes a drag on her cigarette. There is a quiet, sweet pause between them
Oh Geo, we could always go back to London. The two of us.
No thanks.
You know you miss it.
Sometimes I miss it. Maybe if Jim had lived. He loved England. He really wanted us to stay the last time we were there.
Do you really think you would have moved?  63.

Oh, I donвЂ™t know. ItвЂ™s silly to even talk about it. It was just a fantasy. Charley reaches over and holds his hand. As she does, she fondles his little finger and notices the addition of the slim gold band.
WhatвЂ™s this? George pulls his hand away.

My motherвЂ™s wedding ring. I found it when I was cleaning out a drawer. Charlotte dear, we are both in need of another drink George stands up, grabs their two empty glasses, and head back to the drinks table as Charley watches, clearly stil very much in love. Charley gets up and puts on a record and then crosses the room to where George is mixing the drinks and slides up behind him affectionately. George smiles as Charley embraces him from behind and lay her head on his shoulder. Much to her surprise he turns around, takes her hand, and grabs her around the waist as they begin to slow dance. George buries his head in CharleyвЂ™s neck and squeezes h close. We hear the sound of her bracelets and George feel the brush of her earrings as he literally drinks her in. They are drunk and adorable together as the pace of the music slows and George starts to pull away. Charley in an attempt to keep things going stops dancing and runs across the room to change the record.  64.
Wait, wait, wait! DonвЂ™t move. I LOVE this. She puts on a wild record as George begins to laugh again his will.
You are insane!

Come on old man! The music blares and the two of them go crazy. Charley is quite a sexy dancer as is George. He twists lower and low as the two of them have a Watusi competition all the time laughing. As Charley shakes her head and goes wild, she loses her balance in her mules and falls back onto George. The two them fall to the floor laughing. They are both flat on their backs as Charley slides into comfortable spot under George's arm with her head on his shoulder. They slowly calm down and their laughter turns to sweet smiles of exhausted, drunken contentment as the record di down and turns itself off. They look blissful lying on the white shag carpet as they regain their breath.

DonвЂ™t move. George jumps up, slips off his jacket and tosses a few pillows to the floor. He grabs their drinks, CharleyвЂ™s cigarettes and an ashtray and heads back to her. He slides back down next to her, lights two cigarettes at the same time, gives one to her, and takes the other one himself.
Very smooth cigarette move.
I've always wanted to do that.
You donвЂ™t even smoke.
Well, not for the last 16 years. Jim hated. WhatвЂ™s to stop me now. ItвЂ™s not as if itвЂ™s going to kill me is it? They both laugh and blow smoke into the air.
This is so nice lying here with you. DonвЂ™t you ever miss this? What we could have been to each other? Having a real relationship and kids?
(stunned) I had Jim.

I know, but I mean a real relationship. Geo, letвЂ™s be honest, what you and Jim had was great but wasnвЂ™t it really just a substitute for something else? George sits up and looks directly at Charley.
Is that really what you think after all of these years? That Jim was just a substitute for real love? George really loses his temper.
Jim wasnвЂ™t a substitute for anything, and there is no substitute for Jim, anywhere! And (MORE)

by the way, what was so REAL about your relationship with Richard? He left you after 9 years! Jim and I were together for 16 years and if he hadnвЂ™t died we would still be together! What the hell is not REAL about that!? George, disgusted, gets up and stands in front of the fir He stands dead still for a moment trying to compose himse Charley is stunned and doesnвЂ™t move. Charley has been stung by GeorgeвЂ™s comments about her marriage.
I didnвЂ™t mean it the way it sounded. I know how much the two of you loved each other

I just suppose that I was always a bit jealous that you and I never had that kind of love. Actually I've never had that kind of love with anyone. I donвЂ™t think Richard ever loved me except for the way I looked. And Clay, I donвЂ™t know. You raise a child and love it and then when they get old enough they just leave.
Charlotte, there is nothing wrong with your life. You like feeling sorry for yourself. ItвЂ™s one of your great pleasures.
And itвЂ™s not one of yours? You're as pathetic as I am.
Feeling sorry for myself is definitely not one of my great pleasures.  67. Charley struggles to stand up.

Well its not one of mine either. I donвЂ™t like feeling sorry for myself one bit. I tried to hold onto Richard for so long even when it was obvious to everyone but me that it was over. Now Clay is grown up. I mean, what am I doing here Geo? Tell me that?
You have lots of friends. YouвЂ™ll be fine. Charley sighs.

Yes, I have friends. But none of them need me. And yes I have you and if you werenвЂ™t such a goddamn poof we could have all been happy! George begins to smile. Charley crosses to the coffee table, lights another cigarette, takes a long drag and exhales slowly. She sits down on the sofa and George joins her. He slips his arm around her as she attempts to wriggle away.

I only have you now because you lost Jim, but IвЂ™1l lose you again soon to someone else. ItвЂ™s not as easy for a woman. I did everything the way that I was supposed to and all I have to keep me company is a bottle of gin.
Maybe you should try donuts with your gin.
Screw you!  68.

Charlotte, you are dramatic. You really almost had me. A tiny tear was beginning to form in the corner of my eye. Now stop it, you know that you are still breathtakingly beautiful when you bother to get yourself up and out of bed and you stop whimpering about everything for five minutes. Move back to London! Change your life! If you're not happy being a woman then stop acting like one.

You have all the goddamn answers donвЂ™t you? If you're so smart why arenвЂ™t YOU making something new happen in your life? (beat) IвЂ™m serious. Why donвЂ™t you take that position at Stanford? Why do you keep teaching at that little school when you could have any position you want?
I think what IвЂ™ve done has been worthwhile. George is stung.
IвЂ™m sorry, I shouldn't have said that. (beat) As much as I dread it, I think I might move back to London.
Why do you dread it?
When I lived in London last I was YOUNG. I was fresh, I was everything. Coming to America was (MORE )
such a dream, it was the icing on the cake. Going home is defeat. None of it really worked out the way I'd planned.
Most things donвЂ™t work out the way people plan. YouвЂ™re living in the past. You need to start thinking about the future.
Living in the past IS my future. You're a man. It doesnвЂ™t have to be yours. They both sit silently for a moment.
And you're a bore tonight. CanвЂ™t we just feel sorry for ourselves a little bit longer? Mix me up another drink. Please? George checks his watch. 10:45.
I donвЂ™t think so. I have to go. Come on. Walk me out. He gets up and takes his jacket from the back of the sofa
But this was such fun!
I have to. Charley gets up and follows him as they walk toward the entry hall.
When will I see you again?
ArenвЂ™t you moving to London?
IвЂ™1l never do that! ItвЂ™s far too much effort. Besides, I donвЂ™t think Jim would want me to leave you here in LA all alone.
Don't worry about me Charley. IвЂ™m OK. IвЂ™ve got all the answers. Remember?
What are you doing this weekend?
I think I might just be very quiet.
You never really did take me seriously did you George? George opens the door, turns and faces her.

I tried to Charley. Remember? A long time ago. It didnвЂ™t quite work, did it? Good night Charley. As they embrace, she kisses him hard. For a moment he kis her back until her kiss turns serious and desperate. George calmly backs up and looks into her eyes. With both hands, he firmly grips her arms and kisses her again on t mouth but this time it is a chaste good-bye kiss. Charley behaves. She is defeated and we feel that this sc has been played out before in their relationship. GEORGE (CONTвЂ™D) Sleep tight. I love you. She resigns herself to him leaving, and stares at the bac of the door as he closes it behind him. EXT. GEORGEвЂ™S HOUSE SANTA MONICA. NIGHT -- LATER. (1962  71. An exterior shot of the full moon through the trees. George's house is illuminated in the background.
George is sitting at his desk writing a note. George seals the note and then picks up the gun and holds for a moment as he places the gun gently to his head.
George walks up the sidewalk towards the bar. It is a liv scene outside with the bar crowd spilling out onto the sidewalk. George approaches the door and pushes himself inside.

The bar is packed and filled with many men in their Naval uniforms. It is also filled with girls who have clearly dolled themselves up for the evening. All are laughing and talking loudly. It is a wild and raucous atmosphere and filled with so much smoke that it hard to see. George walks in and not being able to find a spot to stan orders a beer and a pack of cigarettes at the bar and goe outside to smoke and enjoy the cool breeze.

George is standing outside enjoying his cigarette as a yo Naval officer walks into the bar. George briefly locks eyes with the young man. After a few moments, the young officer returns with a beer - itвЂ™s J
ItвЂ™s too hot in there.
Yes it is. Would you like a cigarette?
No thanks, I donвЂ™t smoke. Is this place always this crowded?
Well, it is Saturday night but no itвЂ™s usually not quite this bad. Most people just stop in here to pick someone up and then head on down the beach for the rest of the evening.
Yeah. ItвЂ™s pretty wild out there. IвЂ™m surprised the cops donвЂ™t break it up. Is it always like that?
Since the war ended. I think itвЂ™s pretty great actually. Kind of pagan. Jim puts his hand out.
Jim. The two men shake hands.
George. Pleased to meet you Jim.
IвЂ™m supposed to meet some friends here but they're nowhere to be found.
I just needed to get out of the house. I was just going to take a walk but the lure of a cold beer got to me. George puts out his cigarette.
Do you live close by?  73.
Yes. In the canyon.
How long have you lived here?
Since 38. Where are you from?

Colorado. But I really like it here. I think I might stay after IвЂ™m discharged. ItвЂ™s great. I love being so close to the ocean. I donвЂ™t know, perhaps IвЂ™m just a bit of a pagan. Just then it begins to rain lightly. The two men look at each other and then scramble for the door to the bar as t rain starts coming down hard and fast.
It is packed inside and George and Jim are literally pres up against each other. There is an electricity between th two of them. It is so loud inside the bar that they have shout.
Another beer?
That would be great. Just then a beautiful BLONDE GIRL with Veronica Lake hair and a cherry red mouth, pushes between the two of them. A she does she looks up at Jim.
Well, hello.
Hello.  74.
Want to buy me a drink? Jim looks past the girl directly into GeorgeвЂ™s eyes.
I'm afraid IвЂ™m taken.
Too bad. Too bad... She pushes away from them back into the crowd as the two smile at each other.
INT. GEORGEвЂ™S HOUSE - STUDY. NIGHT -- CONTINUOUS George sits still for a moment, puts the gun down, jumps and runs down the hall to the kitchen.

head_text.subj: OUR VIEW IS FROM OUTSIDE OF THE HOUSE.

text: George crosses to the liquor cabinet and grabs the bottle scotch. There is only a drop left. George puts down the bottle, takes off his glasses and go out the front door.

As George leaves his driveway he hears someone behind him We see clearly the outline of KennyвЂ™s bike in the foreg but George doesnвЂ™t see this. He stops and looks around. Nothing. George continues his down the hill.
George approaches the bar. He opens the door and goes in. The place is a faded version of its 1946 incarnation.  75.

The bar now sports a jukebox in the corner and a televisi above it. A neon Budweiser sign/clock tells us it is 11:0 Most of the patrons sit at the long bar, staring lazily a the television in a cow daze. George heads to the bar and calls out to PATRICK the bartender.

Patrick, could I have a bottle of scotch and a pack of Lucky Strikes to go please? As he says this he notices a young man who walks into the bar. A slow steady smile crosses George's face - itвЂ™s Kenny. George looks to the bartender.

Patrick. Cancel that. He holds up two fingers and points to his regular booth. Patrick nods. George walks over to the booth. Kenny slips onto the bench across from George. Kenny is slightly out of breath.
Well, hello Mr. Potter.
Hello, sir. The bartender places their drinks in front of them. KENNY (CONTвЂ™D) What are we drinking?  76.
Scotch.
They each take a sip.
I come here all the time. I live around the corner, but then you know that.

On Camphor Tree Lane. They smile at each other. George reaches into his pants pocket, pulls out his penci sharpener, and places it on the table with a smile. KENNY (CONTвЂ™D) You're still carrying that around.
One must always appreciate life's little gifts. Kenny and George smile at each other.
So what are you doing here?
Just out for a ride on my bike.
Is that all?
I donвЂ™t know.
Were you looking for me?
Maybe. I donвЂ™t know. I feel like my headвЂ™s stopped up with stuff, with crap.
Stuff like what?
Like, the stuff you were talking about today in class.
That is definitely not important.
No, it is important. Your class is great. But somehow we always seem to get stuck talking about the past. The past just doesnвЂ™t matter to me
And the present?
I canвЂ™t wait for the present to be over. ItвЂ™s a total drag. Well tonight's the exception
George bursts into laughter.
What?
Tonight - yes! The present - no! Let's drink to tonight! They clink glasses.
Tonight! They both take a sip.  78.
So if the past doesnвЂ™t matter and the present is a вЂњtotal dragвЂќ. what about the future?
What future? I mean Cuba might just blow us up.
Death is the future.
IвЂ™m sorry. I donвЂ™t mean to be depressing.
ItвЂ™s not depressing, itвЂ™s true. I mean, itвЂ™s not necessarily your immediate future, but itвЂ™s what we all share. Death is the future.
You're right I guess.
If one is not enjoying oneвЂ™s present there isnвЂ™t a great deal to suggest that the future should be any better.
Yeah, IвЂ™ve thought that before. But the thing is, you just never know. Look at tonight. George looks intently at Kenny. KENNY (CONTвЂ™D) Actually I feel really alone most of the time.
You do?  79.

Yeah. IвЂ™ve always felt this way. I mean we're born alone, we die alone. And while we're here we are absolutely, completely sealed in our own bodies. Really weird. Kinda freaks me out to think about it. We can only experience the outside world through our own slanted perception of it. Who knows what you're really like. I just see what I think you're like.
IвЂ™m exactly what I seem to be, if you look closely. You know the only thing that has made the whole thing worthwhile has been those few times that I was able to truly connect with another person
I had a hunch about you, sir.
You did?

Yes, sir. I had a hunch you might be a real romantic. George smiles. KENNY (CONTвЂ™D) You know, everyone keeps telling you that when you're older, that you'll have all this experience - like itвЂ™s some great thing
That's a load of shit. I think IвЂ™ve actually just gotten sillier and sillier.
Really?  80.
Absolutely.
So all your experience is useless?
No, I wouldnвЂ™t say that. As our friend Mr. Huxley says: вЂњExperience is not what happens to a man; it is what a man does with what happens to him.вЂќ Kenny looks at George and then blurts out...
LetвЂ™s go swimming.
Kenny bursts into laughter. George is confused but grins anyway.
What?

It was a test. I thought you were bluffing about being silly, so I said to myself, I'll suggest doing something completely outrageous and if he resists, if he even hesitates - then I know heвЂ™s full of shit.
Well, I wasnвЂ™t. Were you?
Hell no! They both jump up. George throws a few bills on the table and follows Kenny out of the bar.
They break into a run as Kenny sprints across the highway without looking either way. George struggles to keep up.

head_text.subj: EXT. SANTA MONICA STATE BEACH. NIGHT

text: As George runs across the highway - Kenny vaults over the railing and disappears. George clambers over the guard rail and looks down at Ken the street lights shining on his grinning face.
Come on sir. I'll help you down George drops to the sand.
Let's go. Kenny turns and runs, whooping and pulling off his clothe George follows. As he watches Kenny undress he hesitates momentarily and then begins to unbutton his shirt.

A naked Kenny runs toward the surf and fearlessly dives i the waves. Seeing Kenny, George toughens up. He slips off his pants, runs after Kenny and dives in. A wave splashes over George and he stumbles. He finds his balance and continues out. George makes his way out further, still laughing, as Kenn continues to plunge in and out of the waves. Emboldened by Kenny's enthusiasm, George wades out further, his arms outstretched.

head_text.subj: EXT. SANTA MONICA STATE BEACH. NIGHT

text: A naked George is way out and almost out of his depth as towering wave pulls the surf away from him. George tries brace himself against the giant wave but instead he is  82. knocked flat and suddenly pulled underwater. He does not resurface. Kenny dives under water to look for George.
George gasps for air as Kenny pulls him to the surface an drags him toward the beach.
ThatвЂ™s enough for now sir
IвЂ™m fine.
Well IвЂ™m not. IвЂ™m cold. Come on.
Kenny gets George to their clothes and starts toweling himself off.
can we go back to your place sir?
Of course. Where else? George begins dressing.
Where else. Kenny smiles and grabs the rest of his clothes, heading b toward the highway still naked.
Are you out of your mind?
WhatвЂ™s the matter?
You canвЂ™t walk home like that! George catches up with Kenny.
WeвЂ™re invisible, donвЂ™t you know that? 83. George stops dead in his tracks with this line from Kenny George is very cold, but Kenny seems in his element. He p his arm around George's shoulders.
You know sir, they ought not to let you out on your own. You're liable to get into real trouble.
Oh, I excel at it. Kenny looks at George who has a small cut over his left e
Your forehead is bleeding. George reaches up and touches his brow. He looks at his h and sees the blood on his fingers.
They enter the house. Kenny is full of energy and George sobered up a little from the walk back.
The bathroom is down the hall if you would like to take a shower
ArenвЂ™t you taking a shower too, sir?
IвЂ™m fine. IвЂ™m English. We like to be cold and wet.
First, I think that we need to take care of that cut sir. Do you have any band-aids?  84.
Kenny and George walk into the bedroom Kenny looks at the sleeping bag.
Going camping sir?
Really, IвЂ™m fine.
Stay there. I'll be right back George sits down on the sleeping bag.

Kenny walks into the bathroom. He opens the drawer next to the sink and pulls out a cotton ball and a bottle of alcohol. He finds a tin of band-aids. As he lifts it up something catches his eye. It is the nude photograph of dim, taken in the desert. Kenny stares at the picture a moment, looks towards the bedroom, and then quickly puts it back in the drawer.
Kenny returns to the bedroom where George is lying flat o the bed with his feet on the ground.

sit up. George obeys much to his surprise, as Kenny seems suddenl in control. KENNY (CONTвЂ™D) Tilt your head back Kenny gently cleans George's forehead with a cotton ball soaked in alcohol. George winces slightly but his eyes ar locked on his new friend. Kenny puts a band-aid across th  85. cut over GeorgeвЂ™s brow and gently brushes his wet hair with his fingers. KENNY (CONTвЂ™D) Well sir, IвЂ™m afraid this time you donвЂ™t have the excuse of mescaline to explain your bandage.
I think that we need to get you out of those wet clothes.

Yes sir. Kenny stands up and moves to the corner next to a chair. kicks off his shoes and undresses very slowly. He careful lays his clothes on the chair. Standing nude, Kenny turns towards George. He looks shy and nervous. George, who sti sits on the edge of the bed, does not take his eyes off o Kenny. Kenny smiles sweetly at George, but George does not react Suddenly embarrassed, Kenny turns and walks into the bathroom. He doesnвЂ™t close the door after him but is ou of GeorgeвЂ™s sight. The shower is turned on. George is not sure what to do. Looking towards the bathro he contemplates going in but instead rushes to his closet and grabs his robe. INT. GEORGEвЂ™S HOUSE - LIVING ROOM. NIGHT -- MINUTES LAT George lights a fire. He turns on the Hi-Fi and adjusts the lights. Kenny comes into the room, wrapped in a grey blanket.
You're not too cold?
I'm great.
Would you like a drink?  86.
I'd love a beer sir, if you have one.
IвЂ™m afraid thatвЂ™s all we have. Two beers, coming up. Kenny is examining an architectural model next to the drafting table as George arrives and hands him his beer.
You live here all by yourself, sir?
I do now. I used to share this place with a friend. He was an architect.
Man, guys my age dream about the kind of setup youвЂ™ve got here. I mean, what more can you want? You get to be left alone and come and go as you please.
And thatвЂ™s your idea of the perfect life?
WhatвЂ™s the matter, sir? You donвЂ™t believe me?
If you're so keen on living by yourself, where does Lois fit into this plan?
Lois? WhatвЂ™s she got to do with anything?
I had the impression that you and she were together.  87.
Not really. I mean sheвЂ™s kind of cool and we're good friends, but I think what you really want to ask me is if we sleep together
And do you?
We did. Once.
Why only once?
I didnвЂ™t say only once, I said once. Come on, the last thing I want to talk about right now is Lois.
What time is it? George looks at his watch. The second hand is not moving the case is clouded over.
I donвЂ™t know. My watch seems to have stopped. George bangs his watch on the table.
What does it matter anyway.
Would you like me to go?
No, are you kidding? Get us both another beer. Kenny jumps up and heads to the kitchen, then looks back.  88.
Is that an order sir?
You're damn right it is! George tries to get up, but he struggles, quite drunk now and falls back into his chair.
(to himself) Pathetic. Kenny arrives with two bottles of beer.
Were you saying something sir? George gives Kenny a concentrated stare.
Why are you here? Why did you ask the secretary in the office for my address?
I just wanted to see you someplace other than school.
why?
Sometimes I think IвЂ™m crazy because I see things so differently than everyone else does. I feel like I can talk to you. To be honest sir I was also worried about you today.
Me? WhatвЂ™s to be worried about? IвЂ™m fine. George's vision begins to blur as Kenny moves toward us. image fades to a dusky brown.
IвЂ™m fine...  89.

We are underwater in GeorgeвЂ™s recurring dream. From the of our screen drifts the nude body of George, arms outstretched, sinking slowly. He moves his legs in a slig struggle as he drops further and further underwater. Geor begins to toss and turn violently in the water searching air. This time he suddenly rights himself and begins push toward the surface of the water. He climbs higher and hig and hits the surface with a loud gasp for air.

George wakes up in bed with a deep gasp for air. He looks around the room for a moment. He is still dresse in his robe. The light is on. He looks to the chair- KennyвЂ™s clothes are still there. INT. GEORGEвЂ™S HOUSE - STUDY. NIGHT -- CONTINUOUS George walks into the study. In the faint light we see Ke asleep on the sofa underneath the blanket. George stands over Kenny a minute looking at him. The lig is catching on KennyвЂ™s thick lashes. Kenny is breathing gently. He looks angelic, and very, very, young. Kenny's hands are holding onto something under the blanke George carefully pulls the blanket back to reveal Kenny loosely gripping George's gun.
